div.head: Circa textum
div.p:
Nunc postquam coaeternitatem Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 1, n. 1 . This distinction 19 continues the preceding thus because after Lombard determined about the identity of the persons with a real distinction or eternal duration, now he begins to treat about the coequal perfection of the persons. And he divides it into three because in the first place he shows in what things it consists and with respect to what their equality applies in
general, in the second place he shows specifically those things in which they are equal not from a real difference, in the third place he considers one of predicates specifically. The second begins at
cumque enumeratur ista quasi diversa
Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 2, n. 1
etc. The third at
quod autem aeternitate Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 2, n. 5
etc. And this is the division of the present distinction in general

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether any divine supposite immeasurably perfect is in itself infinitely distinct from any other?

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p: That not because no divine supposite is immeasurably perfect which is clear because, just as one is not the other, so the perfection of one is not the perfection of the other because then there would several immeasurably perfect things, one of which would not be the other.

In the second place, the divine supposites are distinguished from one another by their related properties and by the perfection attributes, therefore they are not distinction from them. The consequence holds because these personal properties are not divine supposites, as is seen.

In the third place, the divine supposites are infinitely distinguished in small ways, therefore. The consequence holds because it does not seem compossible that something is infinitely such in small ways and infinitely such. But the antecedent is clear because the divine supposites are distinguished by a real personal distinction which is the smallest possible distinction.

In opposition, it is argued because the divine supposites are distinguished in such a way that in no mode are they able to be the same suppositionally and not another thing from themselves, therefore. The consequence holds because the degree to which identity is repugnant to distinction, to the same degree do they seem to be distinguished among themselves. The first part of the antecedent is clear because by how much necessity God is God, by the same necessity are the three divine supposites. The second part is clear because, if so, it would follows that in the divine essence there would be a quaternity. The consequent is false.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p: The first conclusion: any divinal supposite is immeasurably perfect and equal to the other. The proof is because between divine supposites there is the highest essential identity of perfection of many things, therefore. The consequence holds because the highest essential identity of several distinctions is the highest equality of them. The antecedent is proved because a greater essential identity of several things than the identity of the divine supposites is not able to be imagined.

The first corollary: though supposite being is determined under no perfection, nevertheless the uncreated supposite being is of an immeasurabley perfection. The first part is clear because, if so, the Son would not have every perfection of the Father, nor the converse, which is false. The second part is clear through the conclusion.

The second corollary: no created simple thing or composite is able to be as equal to another as the divine supposites. This is clear because no plural created things are as much the same as the divine supposites are the same

Third corollary: though the equality or identity of any equal things of the creator is infinitely less than the identity of the divine supposites, nevertheless it is not repugnant according to some denomination that only one is the similitude of similar composites. The first is clear because otherwise the identity of the divine supposits would not be the highest possible identity from nature, which is contra to what has been said. The second part is proved because from the absolute power of God the same whiteness would be able to inform two distinct substances. And consequently this would return similar things and designate white things.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
Second conclusion: just as no divine supposite is distinguished from its personal property, so no divine supposite is distinguished from the essential or attributable perfection. The first is proved by taking supposite with the inclusion of the origin, and this is clear through
Jermoe in the Exposition of the catholic faith
Hieronymus, Exposition, xxx
saying
the impiety of the Sabellians who deny the three persons under divinus?? property and place under, for not only the names in this mode but even the names of properties, that is the persons or as they say in Greek the hypostases and subsisting things which acknowledge from these words
Jerome, The Exposition of the Catholic Faith, XXX . The conclusion is clear, and these words are treated below
in distinction 35, in the last chapter XXX . The second part is proved because attributal perfection is the essence itself imported into many things
through a term generally importing a perfection absolutely common to the creator and to the creature according to some analogy from a revealing investigation of creatures into the creature, like wisdom, justice, goodness, and others of this type. But any divine supposite is formally ad really justice, goodness, wisdom, and things of this type, therefore no divine supposite is distinguished from attributal perfection. The first part of the antecedent is clear through the description of the attribute or the attributal perfection, which is able to drawn out from what is said by
Thomas of Strasbourg, in distinction 6 of the first book, in question one, in article one
Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 6, q. 1, a. 1 . Through that which is said generally signifying absolute perfection they differ from notions because, though the generating Father is a kind of perfection absolutely, nevertheless it is not generally because then it would be a perfection in the Son or Holy Spirit. Through that which is said to God and to creature they differ from those things which are not and are not able to be suitable to creatures, like deity, immensity, etc. But through that which is said according to some analogy they differ from those things which we only believe by faith to suit God, and to depend on his free will alone, like to become a man, to be born, to suffer, etc.

First corollary: because the will, intellect, goodness, and attributal perfections of this kind are not and they do not indicate distinct formalities in God. This is clear because otherwise there would be an infinite process in formalities, which is false. The consequence is clear because, if wisdom is formally distinguished from the will, therefore let this distinct formality be a, and it follows that a has another formality, and then it is asked whether this is distinguished from that or that, as before, and thus there will be a proceeding into infinity or there will be admitted that somethings are distinguished formally and they do not have diverse formalities.
Second corollary: every attributable divine perfection within it is formally the same and absolutely equal. This is clear.

Third corollary: though attributes of this type are not pluralized nor distinguished from the nature of things, nevertheless a distinction of reason is had between them or is taken up through the operation of our intellect. The first is clear from what has been said. The second is proved because from the fact that such attributable perfections are not distinguished in God, the plurality of them would not be able to be had unless through distinct conceptions of the same things accepted by creature in whom understanding is one thing, willing is another thing, etc. But such compositions and divisions are operations of our intellect, therefore.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p: Third conclusion: just as equality among many created things recognizable in the equality of the divine supposites is properly incomparable, so the personal distinction of the same divine supposites is disproportional to every other distinction. The first is clear through what has been said since in no case are several created things as essentially the same as these divine supposites are essentially the same. The second part is proved because this personal distinction in a line of distinctions is not of some quantity, since it is the smallest possible. And in the second place because no distinction recognizable among created things is of the same ratio with this, therefore this is disproportional from one to other.

The first corollary: just as two divine supposites are not something greater than one, so one of them is not less distinguished from one than from the remaining two. This is clear because something is distinguished in itself from another.

Second corollary: though amount any two men there is able to be found properly a personal distinction, nevertheless we do not say properly that this distinction will be greater, lesser, or equal to the divine distinction. This is clear because they are of diverse rationes and infinitely and incompossibly disproportionate because it is impossible that one person is another. Nevertheless it is not distinguished infinitely impossibly infinitely differently
such that the person is distinguished infinitely incompossibly and distantly, and nevertheless is distinguished indivisibly because it is the smallest distinction possible.
The third corollary is the affirmative part of the conclusion when taking supposita with the inclusion of their origin.

div.head: Objections
div.p: Against the first conclusion, it follows that there would be in the divine three perfect things in the highest degree. The consequent is false because only one thing can be the most perfect. The consequence is clear because anything of equals such that it is equal to another is to this perfect. But the divine supposite is not equal to another unless to the extent that it is against what is distinct, therefore some divine supposite such that it is distinct from another will be the most perfect, and thus there will be three things that perfect in the highest degree.
In the second place, it follows that there will be infinite equal things in God. This is clear because any attributal perfection will be equal to another.

In the third place against the second corollary, its subject and accident are one in quantity, therefore in as much as something is one in quantity so they are able to be equal. The consequence is clear because quantity is according which we say something is equal or unequal as the Philosopher says.

In the fourth place against the third corollary, it follows that there would be a greater identity of the Son and the Father in the divine than of man to itself. The consequent is false because, just as it is true to say Plato is Plato, so it will be true to say the Father is the Son, which should not be said. But the consequence is proved because the identity of man to itself seems to be identity of many because man is its matter and its form which are its parts and are many.

Against the second conclusion, it would follow that the Father by one and the same relation is referred to the Son and the Holy Spirit. The consequent is false because then conversely the Son and the Holy Spirit are referred by one relation to the Father, and thus there would only be one person. The first consequence is known and the second is proved because it is impossible that one and the same thing will correspond to two relations according to species.

In the second place against the first corollary, wisdom and justice are formally distinguished and from the rationes of them and formalities in creatures, therefore wherever the formalities of them are found, there also distinctions will be found because infinity does not destroy the distinction in the thing.

In the third place against the second corollary, if the attributes were not distinct in God, it follows that power, justice, goodness, and attributes of this type would synonymous names. The falsity of the consequent is clear because they do not seem to signify the same thing nor in the same mode.

In the fourth place against the third corollary, these things are distinguished, one of which is pluralized, while the other has not been pluralized, but the essence is not pluralized, but the attributes have been, otherwise our intellect would invent or would be deceived. The antecedent is clear, for we have one concept of justice, another concept of goodness, and another of mercy.

Against the third conclusion, the divine supposites are distinguished by their properties, therefore one supposite has more properties than another, therefore in a line of a distinction a certain quantity corresponds to this distinction, therefore one internal distinction is proportional or comparable to another distinction.

In the second place, for any property inasmuch as it corresopends from a distinctive ratio in the same degree it corresponds to it from the entitative ratio, but to any divine property the proper entitative ratio corresponds, therefore a proper distinctive ratio, and consequently any property adds a proper distinction above the other.

In the third place against the first corollary and the first conclusion, if the Father is distinguished in himself from the Son, it follows that the Father convenes with the Son in nothing of himself or that the Father does not convene in something of himself with the Son. The consequent is false because then it would not be one and the same essentially in the higheset degree. The consequence is clear because those things which are distinguished in themselves do not convene in something of themselves.

In the fourth place against the responsive corollary, the divine persons are simple things in the highest degree, such that the essence is not simpler than the persons nor is some thinkable property in the persons simpler than the person, therefore by whatever means such a person is distinguished it itself from another, it is distinguished in isolation from any other, therefore it is distinguished by an isolated origin from itself in turn for the others This is the argument of
Gregory, in distinction 26, article one, question 2
Gregorius Ariminensis, I, d. 26, a. 1, q. 2 .

div.head: Responses
div.p:
To the first, the consequence is denied, and to the proof the major is conceded because,
though every divine supposite is immeasurably perfect in incomplex perfection, nevertheless it follows that there are three perfect supposites. See
Hugolinus XXX
. Otherwise it is possible to say that the consequent is true because common predications belong to three persons, and they belong through nouns, adjectives, or participles. If they are held to be pure adjectives, then they always speak about many things, namely about three things plurally and according to this rule they are able to said to be three blessed, three eternal, and so on about similar things. See
Henry of Ghent, first part, article 49, question 3
Henricus Gandavensis, I, a. 49, q. 3 .

To the second, the consequences is denied, and to the proof it is said that between the attributes there is not distinction from the nature of things, as is clear from the third corollary of the second conclusion.
To the third, in the first place it would be possible for the antecedent to be denied because any of them is quantity or an amount in their own quantity.
In the second place, it would be able to be said that the argument is not against the corollary because quantity is from an essential ratio of those amounts.

To the fourth, in the first place it would be possible to be said when admitting the consequent, and when it is further inferred, therefore just as this should be conceded Plato is Plato, etc., this consequence is denied.
In the second place, it is even better able to be said by denying the first consequence because the identity of man to its very self is not properly the identity of many, but of only one man.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequent is conceded, and to the disproof, because then the Son and the Holy Spirit, etc., the consequence is denied because, just as Socrates by the same whiteness in number is able to be similar to Plat and dissimilar to Cicero, so a single relation is able to correspond to two relations.

To the second, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is conceded that divine infinity does not destroy the formal distinction of attributes absolutely, but destroys the formal distinction in God.

To the third, the consequence is denied. To the proof it is said that, though the names thoroughly signify the same thing in the divine, nevertheless they do not signify the same thing in a creature, and therefore they are not synonyms because synonyms signify the same thing thoroughly in whichever thing the signified of those things is found.

To the fourth, the minor is denied. To the proof, I say that, just as the essence is not pluralized, so neither are the attributes pluralized from the nature of the thing in God, though we express the same signified thing through diverse terms. And this is on account of the weakness of our intellect because we are not able to grasp or understand otherwise.

To the first against the third conclusion, the major is conceded, but the minor is denied because, if the Father is generating, the Son is generated, and the Holy Spirit is not generated, and so on for similar things.
In the second place, it is said that there are not more incomplex properties in one than in another because any supposite is its own properties, when speaking intransitively.
In the third place, grated there would be more complex properties, nevertheless because they arise from a single and first distinctive ratio, therefore they add nothing.

To the second, Hugolinus would say that what is assumed is not true because he says in
this distinction, in the first question, in the fourth conclusion
Hugolinus de Orvieto, XXX
that any distinction in the divine is infinitely small, and nevertheless the entity is infinitely great.

In the second place and in a different way, what is assumed is able to be conceded, namely that, it only corresponds, etc., but of so many, and thus the consequences is not valid,
the distinction between the Father and the Son is infinite, therefore they are infinitely distinguished , unless in the sense given and expressed in the last corollary

To the third, it is said that it ought to be understand that they are distinguished in themselves, that is by no other incomplex entity. If nevertheless the consequent is understood that the Father does not convene in the essence with the Son, it would be denied because the essence belongs to each. Again, concerning what Hugolinus says that divine persons are distinguished in themselves in a degree of distinction since any person in their own entity is essentially the same thing that another person is because they are essentially one in the highest degree. And he says further that it does not belong to some of it as if some part, but they are essentially one in total.
To the fourth, it is said in the first place that this plurality is not repugnant to simplicity, just as multiplicity of the persons is not repugnant to the simplicity of the essence.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that the corollary does not say absolutely that the persons are distinguished,
but says that the are not distinguished among themselves without the inclusion of the origin, therefore the argument does not conclude.

To the first argument in the opposition, the consequence is denied because one is the perfection of the three persons made plural. And to the confirmation, because the it is called perfect as if perfectly made, it is true according to the imposition of the name, but not according to the property of signification.
To the second, it is clear from the conclusion that the divine supposites are their own properties and attributable perfections.
To the third, it is clear through the third conclusion and corollaries how and how great is the distinction of the divine supposites.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Nunc postquam Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 1, n. 1 . First conclusion: that according to the catholic faith there are three coeternal and coequal divine persons
Second conclusion: that none of the divine persons precede the other in eternity or exceed the other in magnitude or surpass the other in power.

The third conclusion: that though these three, namely eternity, magnitude, and power are enumerated as if diverse things in God, nevertheless they are one and the same, namely the divine essence, simple, and unchangeable.

Fourth conclusion: that the Father is not greater than the Son, nor are the Father and the Son greater than the Holy Spirit, nor two persons a greater something at the same time than one, and nor is a three something greater than two, nor is the essence greater in two or three things than in one because the whole is in the individuals.
The fifth conclusion: that the Son is in the Father and the Father in the Son and the Holy Spirit in each and the individuals in the individuals on account of the unity of the divine nature.

Sixth conclusion: that none of the three divine persons is part of the divine being or the divine essence because each of them is the true and full God and likewise is the whole and full divine essence , and therefore none of them in the trinity is a part.

Seventh conclusion: is that three divine persons are said to be one essence, not according to a material cause, as three statues are said to be one gold, nor on account of the likeness of complexion, as three men are said to be of one nature or sex, nor is the divine essence predicated of the divine persons, as a genus of a species, nor as a species of individuals, nor as something containing of things contained, nor as greater of lesser things.

Eight conclusion: God is said to be triune or a trinity, but by this he is not said to be threefold, for there is not triplicity where there is the highest unity and indifferent equality. However in bodily things one is not as much as three at the same time and two things are more than one, but in the highest Trinity one person is as much as three at the same time and two are as much as one and infinity because there is no end of their magnitude.
